children.subject: Thanks.  This will help a lot.  I've already spent a lot of time working through the practice problems.  By looking at examples in the book, I can manage to work through them.  But after working another problem and going back to rework the previous problem, it's still a challenge.  Hopefully this will help work out the kinks.
I had no idea about that.  Good idea.  Thanks.
Thanks... Perhaps this post should be pinned?
I just noticed that hw1 isn't due until 1pm ET instead of the usual 8am. I'll definitely be using those extra hours!

history.content:
Hi all,

I've extended HW1 on DP, it's now due one week later on Monday September 4.  It's important you do a lot of practice DP problems.  So please use the extra time to work on the practice DP problems from Chapter 6 of [DPV].  I will post solutions to those later in the week, but it's best if you first try them yourself and hopefully figure out the solution on your own (do ask us for help if you need a hint or help, or to check your solution).  

The schedule for the next two homeworks before exam 1 is also posted now, see:

    https://8803ga.wordpress.com/hws/

I will post the next homework on RSA early next week.

For the DP lectures, there are 3 lectures.  I've marked the 3rd lecture DP3 as supplemental on the course schedule.  I won't test you on anything specific in that lecture, but it still may be useful to watch as it's more practice solving DP problems.  

In general, I try to minimize the amount of material you need to memorize.  I won't ask you to regurgitate pseudocode for an algorithm I went through in lecture.  I may ask you the running time but that you can figure out on the fly if you remember the high-level approach.  For example, I don't remember the pseudocode for Dijkstra's algorithm.  But I do remember that it uses the same approach as BFS which is linear time O(n+m).  In addition it uses the min-heap data structure to deal with the edge weights, and each min-heap operation takes O(logn) time.  Thus, Dijkstra's algorithm takes O((n+m)logn) time. The most important aspect I'll stress: I'll try to get you to use the key ideas in the algorithms we've seen in lecture to new problems on the homeworks and exams.   For example, take the idea of the knapsack DP algorithm and apply it to a new DP problem.

--Eric
